I.  THE ENSUING PROGRAM 
1.  To aid the recovery of the current account deficit and promote macroeconomic stability 
and sustained high growth, the proposed Trade and Competitiveness Program aims to encourage 
trade, increase exports, and improve the competitiveness of domestic industries in Pakistan. 
Macroeconomic stability, in turn, implies stronger resilience to adverse economic shocks. This is 
of critical importance in Pakistan as the country pursues increased global competitiveness and 
prosperity to become one of the top 10 largest economies by 2047 as part of Vision 2025.1 The 
program will (i) introduce important tariff and tax policy reforms to support Pakistan’s exporting 
industries and improve their global competitiveness; and (ii) strengthen key institutions involved 
in facilitating trade, including accreditation bodies and the EXIM Bank of Pakistan. A program 
amount of $700 million is proposed to be financed by a concessional ordinary capital resources 
loan. The program is consistent with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country partnership 
strategy for Pakistan, 2015–2019 and is included in the country operations business plan, 2018–
2020.2 The programmatic approach will finance two subprograms to be implemented during 
2018–2019. The transaction technical assistance (TA) is included in the country operations 
business plan, 2019–2021.3 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The Government of Pakistan requested TA to support government initiatives to implement 
critical structural reforms in selected areas under the Pakistan Trade and Competitiveness 
Program. The results framework, implementation arrangements, cost estimate, and the scope of 
the TA were discussed with the government during the consultation mission for the proposed 
policy-based loan. 
 
3.  The  TA  will  support  the  government  in  implementing  reforms  to  improve  the 
competitiveness of domestic industries and increase exports by strengthening the capacity of key 
institutions  related  to  facilitating  trade  and  service  delivery.  The  TA  will  also  support  the 
preparation  and  implementation  of  the  proposed  policy  actions  under  the  Trade  and 
Competitiveness Program. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
4.  Output 1: Tariffs and taxes rationalized. Output 1 will identify specific goods import 
tariffs, regulatory duties, and domestic taxes (e.g., corporate income tax, goods and services tax) 
to be adjusted to have a positive impact on competitiveness. The TA will provide policy advice to 
the government on the recommended rate adjustments in line with fiscal strategies and the 
strategic trade policy framework, 2018–2023. The TA will also advise on the reduction of tariff and 
nontariff barriers on imports of goods used in the textile, clothing, and leather sectors to improve 
competitiveness of exporters. 
 
5.  Output 2: Trade facilitation services strengthened. Output 2 will (i) upgrade national 
standards bodies; (ii) improve metrology, calibration, and product testing capabilities; (iii) establish

international standard certification services; and (iv) strengthen accreditation bodies. The TA will 
help  the  government  operationalize  the  National  Single Window  system  and  establish  the 
e-commerce act and rules. The TA will also provide comprehensive training to agency staff.  
 
6.  Output  3:  Trade  finance  developed.  Output  3  will  strengthen  trade  finance  and 
institutional  governance  by  supporting  the  government  in  designing  and  implementing  a 
transparent governance structure and establishing a statutory act for the EXIM Bank of Pakistan. 
The TA will also support the government in consolidating existing trade finance schemes currently 
managed by the State Bank of Pakistan with the EXIM Bank of Pakistan.4  
 
7.  Output 4: Export products promoted. Output 4 will (i) support the government in the 
international promotion of products and (ii) provide recommendations for increasing the value 
addition and competitiveness of export products in specific sectors (including textiles, clothing, 
and leather). 
 
8.  Output  5:  Training  and  workshops  delivered.  Output  5  will  provide  training  and 
workshops for departments and agencies (including the Ministry of Finance, national standards 
and  accreditation  bodies,  and  the  EXIM  Bank  of  Pakistan).  Workshops  will  be  related  to 
rationalizing tariffs and taxes, improving trade facilitation services, developing trade finance, and 
promoting trade.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $850,000, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 1. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to 
finance the ensuing program. 
 
10.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of staff remuneration, office 
accommodation and supplies, local transport, and other logistical support. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  The implementation arrangements for the TA will be aligned to those of the policy-based 
loan. ADB’s Central and West Asia Department will administer the TA and select, supervise, and 
evaluate consultants and procure goods (if necessary). The Economic Reforms Unit of the 
Ministry of Finance will be the executing agency. The Ministry of Finance, the Federal Board of 
Revenue, and the Ministry of Commerce and Textiles will be the implementing agencies. The TA 
components will be monitored by a senior officer from the Ministry of Finance. The TA will be 
implemented from August 2018 to July 2020 (Table 1). 
   
                                                
4  A separate knowledge and support TA will also support the EXIM Bank of Pakistan. ADB teams will coordinate to 
ensure that TA activities do not overlap.

12.  Consulting services. A total of 48 person-months of consultancy services will be required 
intermittently (Table 2). International and national consultants will be engaged individually or as a 
firm using the quality- and cost-based selection method with a standard quality–cost ratio of 90:10. 
Consulting  services  will  be  selected  and  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  the  ADB 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions. Output-based, lump-sum consulting contracts 
will be preferred. All disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).5
